abstract: Joseph D. Ament, a principal at law firm Much Shelist Denenberg Ament and Rubenstein in Chicago, suggests there is a middle ground in the controversy on how to tax carried interest. Mr. Ament is also a professor of taxation and accounting at Roosevelt University’s Walter E. Heller College of Business Administration.
lead_paragraph: Joseph D. Ament, a principal at law firm Much Shelist Denenberg Ament and Rubenstein in Chicago, suggests there is a middle ground in the controversy on how to tax carried interest. Mr. Ament is also a professor of taxation and accounting at Roosevelt University’s Walter E. Heller College of Business Administration.
